title: 109_s814
content:
The Act titled "Coal Leasing Amendments Act of 2005" requires financial assurances for bonus bids. The Mineral Leasing Act is amended to exempt certain lessees from providing financial assurance for deferred bonus bid installments on coal leases if they have a history of timely payments. The Secretary may waive this requirement for leases issued before the amendment if the lessee has a history of timely payments. If a lessee under a coal lease fails to pay a deferred cash bonus bid installment within 10 days of notice, the lease will automatically terminate, and any bonus payments made will not be returned or credited in future lease sales. SEC. 3. MINING PLANS.

Amends the Mineral Leasing Act to allow the Secretary to establish a period of more than 40 years for mining plans if it ensures maximum economic recovery of coal deposits or promotes orderly development. 

SEC. 4. REPEAL OF THE 160-ACRE LIMITATION FOR COAL LEASES.

Removes the 160-acre limitation for coal leases under the Mineral Leasing Act.

SEC. 5. PAYMENT OF ADVANCE ROYALTIES UNDER COAL LEASES. The Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 is amended to include conditions for diligent development and continued operation of mines under leases, with provisions for suspension of operation conditions by the Secretary of the Interior on payment of advance royalties based on coal market prices. The Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 is amended to include provisions for advance royalties in lieu of continued operation for up to 20 years. Production royalties can be reduced by advance royalties not used in previous years, but not below zero. This applies to any lease or logical mining unit. The Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 is amended to allow for advance royalties in lieu of continued operation for up to 20 years. This applies to existing leases or logical mining units. Section 39 of the Act is amended to remove the authority to waive, suspend, or reduce advance royalties. SEC. 6 eliminates the deadline for submitting coal lease operation and reclamation plans. SEC. 7 addresses inventory requirements. In this section, "compliant coal" contains 1.0-1.2 pounds of sulfur dioxide per million Btu, while "supercompliant coal" has less than 1.0 pounds. The Secretary, in consultation with other departments, will review coal assessments to identify public land with coal resources and any restrictions on their development. The Secretary will complete an inventory of compliant and supercompliant coal resources on identified public land within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Updates will be made as new data and technology advancements arise. A report will be submitted to relevant committees upon completion of the inventory. The Secretary will complete an inventory of coal resources on public land within 2 years of the Act's enactment, with updates as needed. A report will be submitted to relevant committees. The amendments made by this Act apply to any coal lease issued before, on, or after the date of enactment.
